title: Can you give an example of a case where knowledge from a book was more useful than knowledge from experience? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer is that experience is nearly always more valuable with one exception. You don’t need to touch a fire to discover you can get burned. There is a saying I am fond of. “There are 3 kinds of people. Stupid people, smart people and wise people. A stupid person makes the same mistakes over and over. A smart person learns from their mistakes. A wise person learns from the mistakes of others.” Readers who learn from the people they read about, whether fictional or real, benefit from not having to experience the consequences represented in the book. This is one of the most valuable benefits of being well-read. Learning from history, learning from the misadventures of characters in a fiction book, these are extremely valuable and mean you don’t have to go through those experiences in your own life.
Any case can apply to this because books give multiple points of view whereas experience although it might make you learn better, will be biased, so may not be accurate.
